channel.title: New plugin system for DarkQuest?
channel.description:
I think it's safe to say the current plugin system for darkquest is horrid.. for those of you who don't know (which im fairly sure everyone with access to this section does), DarkQuest uses a thread-per-action approach in it's plugin handler, within the plugins you can find a lot of nasty stuff including, but not limited to, [i]Thread.sleep()[/i], yuck! I truly find the infinite amount of threads (even though they're reused) disgusting.
With that being said, I thought of ways to redesign the plugin system..
The thing I hate most about developing plugins (or any game content for that matter) in all RSCD sources is Java's verbosity. Namely the classes DelayedEvent, and MenuHandler. I find that this issue can be resolved with implementing a scripting language with lambda capabilities as the primary content handler such as Jython, or JRuby
The next issue (of which I started the topic with), is the infinite amount of threads, and sleeping they do! After browsing some topics here on MoparScape, I found a post by super_, which introduced me to continuations. This, this, this, will be a life saver.. implementing continuations in DarkQuest would improve it's efficiency by 200% (a little over reacting, but you get my point).
What are y'alls opinions on these ideas?

item.title: New plugin system for DarkQuest?
item.dc:creator: @Peter Peeter
item.description:
@Peter wrote:

If you’re going to replace the plugin language, go for Javascript (it may not be as elegant for some higher level developers, but the community will accept it a lot easier than anything else). The reason DarkQuests threaded plugin system is I was too lazy to implemented it in Javascript. Take a look at RhinoJS, or something similar.

As for the plugin system being horrible, fuck you :D. I’m actually rather proud of it. As far as I’ve seen (considering my inactivity from this scene) it’s the only attempt to separate the core game-server from the content, making it easily extendable/a bit more modular.

Read full topic

item.title: New plugin system for DarkQuest?
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

Neither was I, at first, but I grew on it. You can write most things like you do in java, little stuff like semicolons, empty parenthesis (sometimes), and even the period when calling functions, can all be eliminated in scala.

As for continuations in jython… i’m not so sure even python has support for them? I know in java and scala, it requires modified bytecode, im not really sure how jython works though. I do know that Ruby has them built in the language (as a library), called Fibers, which make more sense. I would assume JRuby has them as well.

[code=scala]import java.util.{Timer,TimerTask}

val timer = new Timer()

def sleep(delay: Int) = shift { k: (Unit => Unit) =>
timer.schedule(new TimerTask {
def run() = k() // in a real program, we’d execute k on a thread pool
}, delay)
}

reset {

println(" no threads!")
